content.description:
Start on the well chalked, horizontal/diagonal crack, and ascend up the right-leaning crack with liberal use of your feet. Continue up similar right-leaning holds and pull up and over.

The downclimb is on the southwest of the boulder. Take your time. There are a few good steps to use, you may want to check it out before climbing this or the other routes on the boulder.

Climbing over the water provides an amazing view while ascending, the location is amazing.

This route has definitely been done before. If the FA or proper route name is known, I'll update the route.
content.protection: Don't fall. A crash pad would most definitely get soaked, so climb smart.
content.location: This route is on the southeast side of the boulder. Either wade through the water to get to the start from the east side or traverse from the downclimb (west side) out right until you're on a small dry patch at the base. I recommend the traverse.

content.description: Traverse across the east face of the boulder on small crimps and sidepulls with tricky footwork.  Begin with both hands on the left arete, and traverse to the right, staying a foot or so off the ground all the way to the large edge on the right arete, then topout. I'm sure this problem has been done before. If anyone has first ascent info, that can be added. The feet change a little every year as the water washes against the base of the boulder.
content.location: It is on the East face of Riverside Boulder.

content.description: A short but sweet climb.  Start on the right side of the face and use a left hand, triangular pinch to dyno to a jug hold on the arete. Easy top out.
content.protection: A pad to cover the pesky rock at the base.

content.description: This is a super classic traverse starting on the downclimb slab and skirting the boulder on the creek side. A blast, don't splash!
content.protection: No pads can be used due to the creek directly below.
content.location: It is on the creek side of the Riverside Boulder.

content.description: Climbs the left side of the west face using face and arete holds.  Traverse the top lip slightly to the right to gain an easy top out. Nice and fun.
content.protection: A pad.  It has a good landing.

content.description: This one climbs the center of the west face.  Moves through small edges to a RH gastone, then to a LH sidepull rail before hitting the top.  Crimpy and technical.  It looks like there are a few possible variations.
